awd_titl_txt: Relating Fukaya Categories Using Combinatorics, Operads, and Nonlinear Elliptic Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Symplectic manifolds are the modern mathematical setting for classical dynamical systems. For instance, consider the motion of the Earth, the Moon, and a satellite, under the influence of gravity. The state of this system can be described by the positions and momenta of the three bodies, and the collection of all possible states is an example of a symplectic manifold. Physical laws, such as the conservation of energy and of momentum, restrict how this system can evolve. The goal of this project is to understand relationships between different symplectic manifolds, and specifically to understand how the restrictions on trajectories, such as those arising from conservation laws, can be translated from one symplectic manifold to another. While progress has been made toward this goal, the PI has proposed the first comprehensive approach. This project has a significant combinatorial component, which is an ideal point-of-entry for undergraduates. The PI is currently supervising an undergraduate research project, and aims to continue involving undergraduate and graduate students in his research program.
 

Specifically, the PI aims to construct a single algebraic object, the "symplectic (A-infinity,2)-category Symp", which binds together the Fukaya categories of symplectic manifolds into a single structure. This extends earlier work of Wehrheim-Woodward, in which those authors associate functors between Fukaya categories to Lagrangian correspondences. Besides this central component, the PI's proposed project involves three other elements. First, the PI will compute portions of Symp in some concrete situations. The PI has begun to develop techniques for computing the functors associated to Lagrangian correspondences in the context of symplectic reduction, and plans to continue these explorations. In particular, he is working with Ritter to builds on earlier work by Ritter-Smith in order to suggest a strategy for understanding how the Fukaya category changes under complex blowup. Second, the PI will explore connections to other fields. Formulating the combinatorial structures necessary for Symp led the PI to construct the 2-associahedra, which are intricate abstract polytopes which fit in well with several existing combinatorial objects. In joint work with Alexei Oblomkov, the PI is constructing complexified versions of 2-associahedra, which form a rich new family of proper log-smooth complex varieties with a close relationship to M_{0,n}-bar. Another connection is to the theory of higher categories: Symp will be an (A-infinity,2)-category, a new algebraic structure which the PI intends to show is a convenient model for certain (infinity,2)-categories. Finally, the PI aims to understand the ramifications of the symplectic (A-infinity,2)-category for symplectic cohomology, an important invariant of a noncompact symplectic manifold. Indeed, understanding the role of unit 1-morphisms in Symp should enable the PI to equip symplectic cohomology with a chain-level algebraic structure, as conjectured by Abouzaid.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Southern California Dept of Contracts & Grants

por.por_cntn:
Symplectic geometry is an active area at the interface of geometry and physics, concerned with the shapes of mechanical systems. In recent years powerful tools, collectively called "Floer theory" have emerged for measuring the complexity of the resulting systems and their allowable physical trajectories. Two specific types of Floer theory of relevance to the study of this project are the "Fukaya category," which collates measurements associated to trajectories with different but constrained start and end-points, and "symplectic cohomology" or "Hamiltonian Floer cohomology" which extract measurements from periodic physical trajectories that return to their starting point at some future time. 

This project sought to explore interactions between measurements in Floer theory coming from two different sources: First, geometric relationships between different physical systems arising in the theory of "Lagrangian correspondences," are expected to introduce strong relationships between Fukaya categories of different targets. Second, symmetries of an underlying physical system and its measurements have notable but not yet fully understood consequences for Floer theory.

The first outcome of this project was the theoretical development of the algebraic and geometric structures expected to control the different ways in which Lagrangian correspondences and their Floer theory relate different Fukaya categories. It was previously understood that there is a complicated geometric pattern tracking different ways in which collections of Lagrangian correspondences can be applied to the Fukaya category, analogous to the parameter spaces tracking various types of multiplication arising in the theory of operads in topology. The project further developed the geometric and combinatorial structure of the relevant patterns, studied natural contexts in which these and analogous patterns arise in other areas within geometry, and developed closely related multiplication structures which should be relevant to the theory of symplectic cohomology.

The second outcome of this project concerned symmetries of the measurements underlying symplectic cohomology. There are two natural such symmetries, one coming continuously rotating the starting position of a given periodic trajectory, and another coming from discretely rotating by a fixed fraction (e.g., 1/2) of the length of the trajectory. Each underlying symmetry induces a refined measurement, known as an "equivariant" symplectic cohomology, and the project related the equivariant symplectic cohomologies associated to the different types of symmetries (continuous versus discrete) by a comparison formula paralleling the widely applied Gysin sequence in topology. In a related vein, the project explored the interaction of discrete symmetries with product structures, formulating under certain hypotheses an algebraic model of equivariant multiplications on symplectic cohomology.

The project also explored potential future directions in these and related areas. The topics developed in this project have so far provided training and discussion subject material for 9 PhD students and 7 postdocs (including current and previous).


Last Modified: 10/29/2024
Modified by: Sheel C Ganatra
